For example, we would be able to see partially formed eyes that would not fully function.
 
 
 And we do. In some phyla, most of the partially-formed examples still exist. You can find them in mollusks, for example.
 
 http://www.pnas.org/content/vol104/suppl_1/images/large/zpq0120756920001.jpeg
 
 
Furthermore, we would expect to see partially formed immune systems, 

 
 Yep:
 
 The descent of the antibody-based immune system by gradual evolution
 Jan Klein*† and Nikolas Nikolaidis*‡
 *Department of Biology and ‡Institute of Molecular Evolutionary Genetics, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802
 
 The antibody-based immune system (AIS) is one of many means by which organisms protect themselves against pathogens and parasites. The AIS is present in jawed vertebrates (gnathostomes) but absent in all other taxa, including jawless vertebrates (agnathans). We argue that the AIS has been assembled from elements that have primarily evolved to serve other functions and incorporated existing molecular cascades, resulting in the appearance of new organs and new types of cells. Some molecules serving other functions have been appropriated by the AIS, whereas others have been modified to serve new functions, either after the duplication of their encoding genes or through the acquisition of an additional function without gene duplication. A few molecules may have been created de novo. The deployment and integration of the ready-made elements gives the impression of a sudden origin of the AIS. In reality, however, the AIS is an example of an organ system that has evolved gradually through a series of small steps over an extended period.
 
 
nervous systems,
 
 
 Yep. For example, all metazoans have a primitive innate immune system. Most vertebrates have them, but agnathans (lampreys and hagfish) don't have only the innate system, and lack the sophisticated adaptive system of other vertebrates. They do have a semi-functional adaptive system, however. As you suggest, this is just what one would expect from evolved organisms.
 
 
digestive systems etc. 

 
 Yep. Cephalochordates merely have a mouth, a hepatic caecum, an iliocolonic ring and an anus. More advanced chordates have increasingly complex digestive systems. Again, just what you'd expect from evolved organisms.

 Here is the argument for irreducible complexity in a nutshell. There are many examples of molecular machines, that are composed of numerous elements. Irreducible complexity rightly shows that such machines are irreducibly complex in that if any one part were removed, the function in question would be instantly lost. How then could such a machine be built up gradually if it will not work to any selectable degree until all its parts are present in their proper order?
 
 Michael Behe, the originator of this argument describes irreducible complexity as "a single system which is composed of several interacting parts that contribute to the basic function, and where the removal of any one of the parts causes the system to effectively cease functioning". An irreducibly complex system cannot be produced gradually by slight, successive modifications of a precursor system, since any precursor to an irreducibly complex system is by definition nonfunctional. Since natural selection requires a function to select, an irreducibly complex biological system, if there is such a thing, would have to arise as an integrated unit for natural selection to have anything to act on. It is almost universally conceded that such a sudden event would be irreconcilable with the gradualism Darwin envisioned.
 
 Now add to this argument the fact that evolutionists will adjust and redefine their standard principles upon which natural selection by way of random mutations is based in order to counter this opposing view, and we see that they can't be consistent in their beliefs but must constantly redefine them in order to remain what appears to be a workable theory. Not consistent, just workable. Evolution shouldn't have to change the very premise upon which it is based in order to survive scrutiny. All available new evidence should fit neatly in its original package of assumptions if it is in fact a real and accurate scientific endeavor. 
 
 Sure, they will write papers which attempt to explain and justify their pseudo science, which is more a philosophy than science in leu of this and other contradictory arguments, but they can't prove any of their claims with any solid evidence at all from the fossil record which they base their fallacious theory on. They will produce so called evidence from controlled experiments under laboratory conditions which set out to manipulate genes by artificially adding proteins and then claim this is evidence of it happening naturally. But we all know that is evidence of nothing more than gene manipulation by an intelligent designer which proves our point to any rational observer. 
 
 Of course rationality is not a function of the evolutionists reasoning so we find ourselves at an uncrossable impasse between the secular based philosophy of evolution and the spiritually based philosophy of scriptural creationism. So it is, and so it shall remain until the Lord returns and these people see with their own eyes how wrong they have been.

that's why I wanted clarification on the use of the word 'adaptive'.

 
 I should probably just let the biologists among us handle this, but what the heck? Let's see how decent my layman's grasp of biology is.
 
 For any entity that replicates itself, a feature is "adaptive" when it enables that entity and its subsequent copies to produce more copies of themselves than they would have been able to make without that feature.
 
 By contrast, a feature is "maladaptive" when it enables a replicator and its subsequent copies to produce fewer copies of themselves than they would have been able to make without that feature.
 
 And a feature is "neutral" when it enables a replicator and its subsequent copies to produce neither more nor fewer copies of themselves than they would have been able to make without that feature.
 
 Whether a given feature of a given replicator is adaptive, maladaptive, or neutral depends on circumstances external to the replicator, including not only non-replicating phenomena and conditions, but also other replicators.
 
 Just a layman's assessment. Feedback would be appreciated (especially from any of our more biologically knowledgeable forum-mates).
 
 
...these molecules seem to replicate themselves perfectly or not at all. Which would not be 'adaptive' replication, as I mentioned earlier. Now I may have missed something obvious here....

 
 From the third paragraph of the section of the article titled "Immortalizing Molecular Information":
 
 "Most of the time the replicating enzymes would breed true, but on occasion an enzyme would make a mistake by binding one of the subunits from one of the other replicating enzymes. When such 'mutations' occurred, the resulting recombinant enzymes also were capable of sustained replication, with the most fit replicators growing in number to dominate the mixture."
 
 Not entirely "obvious," I suppose -- especially not with a head cold! :) -- but it's there. Imperfect copies do get made, and they even copy themselves, too.
 
 Lastly -- by way of connection to your discussion of teleology with Peeling -- note that the quantitative dominance of some replicators over others is not a final cause but a final effect. The literally mindless molecules do not "intend" or "desire" or "strive for" or "hope for" such an outcome. And the researchers don't, either. It is, perhaps, a predictable effect, thanks to the current state of our knowledge of evolution. But predicting an effect doesn't make that effect a cause.
 
 What we have here is adapatation (per the definition I provided above) -- with no teleology necessary.

We do it because in every case that has been investigated we have found precursors. Are eyes IR? Certainly, but there are lots of examples of precursor type eyes. The claim isn't that the examples given by IDists are not IR. The claim is that they did develop through precursors. IDists claim that IR structures could not possibly have evolved. The claim has been repeatedly debunked by showing that they could have. In fact, Behe's first poster child of IR, even though it may have arisen by design in one step, the mouse trap, was shown to be not IR.
 
And, just to be sure, what do you mean when you use the word, "adaptive"?
It is a reference to the fit of an organism to its environment. Changes are adaptive if they result in increased fitness, i.e., if they offer the organism an advantage in survival to reproduction.

Here is the argument for irreducible complexity in a nutshell. There are many examples of molecular machines, that are composed of numerous elements. Irreducible complexity rightly shows that such machines are irreducibly complex in that if any one part were removed, the function in question would be instantly lost. How then could such a machine be built up gradually if it will not work to any selectable degree until all its parts are present in their proper order?

 I think it's unfair of people to condemn you for accepting this argument at face value, because it does seem awfully plausible. Nevertheless, here in a nutshell of roughly equivalent size is one illustration of why the argument is in fact meaningless.
 
 Stone arches. According to 'irreducible complexity', it is impossible for a stone arch to have been built up gradually, because if you remove even one stone, the whole thing collapses.
 
 What has IC missed here? Scaffolding. Stone arches are build over wooden scaffolding, which is then removed. The last gradual step was therefore the removal of a part, not the addition of one. IC misses this possibility completely.
 
 Scaffolding in a simple model of irreducible complexity evolving stepwise
